title: New app tells tourists when they fall into ATM trap
text:
Many families travelling abroad this half term will have fallen into a common currency trap that costs British holidaymakers a fortune every day.

When a tourist withdraws currency from an ATM in a foreign country they are usually presented with such confusing options on screen that they end up paying more than they need to in foreign exchange fees.

It is a legal scam that The Mail on Sunday has warned about for years – yet little has been done to stop the practice.

Foreign exchange fees: TransferWise has developed a feature on its app to alert you of the trap

When travellers insert their card into an ATM they are faced with baffling choices over whether to make the exchange in their own currency or in the local currency.

Online currency transfer service TransferWise says the problem is so bad – affecting more than 1,000 customers who use its debit card every day – that it has developed a feature on its app to alert them when they have fallen into the trap.

Though this is after the event, the hope is that card users will not repeat the mistake the next time they are asked to choose – a choice that can also be presented to them at hotels and in shops. The right answer on such occasions is to opt for the local currency – always.

This avoids you facing double exchange charges. But the wording used by the banks abroad does not make it easy.

If you are in Spain, for example, the screen will present two options: ‘yes for British pounds’ and ‘no for euros’.

Since ‘no’ feels negative – and you are more familiar with your home currency – the natural response is to press ‘yes’. But this is the wrong decision and can end with a customer typically paying 6 per cent (sometimes 12 per cent) more in conversion charges, according to research by TransferWise.

Industry body UK Finance calculates that this so-called ‘dynamic currency conversion’ costs British tourists abroad more than £1million a day.

But there are plenty of other confusing phrases to beware of. If you see ‘continue with conversion’ and ‘continue without conversion’ – choose the latter. Presented with ‘debit in your home currency, or debit in the local currency’ – choose ‘local currency’.

And if you are offered ‘let us convert the money for you – yes or no’ – just say ‘no’.

TransferWise chief executive Kristo Kaarmann developed the new feature which flashes up a message ‘Remember to pay in the local currency’ – and includes a calculation on how much you would have saved had you made the correct choice.

He says: ‘There’s no regulation currently banning this, so I developed the feature to help prevent customers getting ripped off.’
